## Moving water through the plant is vital
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: right; width: 50%;">

* **Most transport materials dissolve in H~2~0**

<br/>

* **Water is component of photosynthesis**  

<br/>

* **Water keeps cells turgid**
    + manipulated in guard cells

<br/>

* **Water is weird and cool**
    + heavy
    + viscous (thick & *sticky*)

 </div>

## Simple Transport: Diffusion through a membrane
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 53%;">

* **Membranes can be free, impermeable or selective**

<br/>

* **Some membranes have aquaporins (proteins) to speed things up**

<br/>

* **Membranes have *molecular pumps* for active transport**
    + use ATP to force molecules across membranes

<br/>

* **Water enters roots through osmosis**
    + often as nutrient solution
    
</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:600px; WIDTH:450px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/aquaporin.jpg">

## Water has the capacity to do work: Water Potential
<hr>

<div style="float: left; width: 58%;">

* **Water has free energy (chemical potential)**
    + in botany = water potential($\psi$)
    + $\psi$ of pure water = 0 (no solutes)
 
<br/>

* **Water potential can be increased/decreased**
    + heated
    + pressure
    + elevated
    
<br/>


* **$\psi$ determined by pressure, solutes & stickiness**

<br/>

* **Movement of water is related to water potential**
    + moves towards more negative $\psi$ (more solutes)
    + cells interconnected = plant one big pond
    
<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:250px; LEFT:750px; WIDTH:300px; HEIGHT:300px" SRC="images/beaker.jpg">

## Plant cell walls will never burst!
<hr>
<div style="float: left; width: 58%;">

* **Example: Plant cells (-.3 mPa) placed in pure water**
    + water will move in to cell

<br/>

* **Example: Plant cells (-.15 mPa) placed in -0.3 solution**
    + water will move our of cell

<br/>

* **Both these changes would need drastic adjustments of H~2~O or solutes**
    + each cause cell death

<br/>

* **Cell walls push or pull against change = pressure potential**
    + part of water potential calculation
    + more 'flexibility' to reach equilibrium

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:175px; LEFT:700px; WIDTH:300px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/turgid2.jpg">

## Phloem: uses active transport & water potential
<hr>
<br/>

* **Source: sites where sugars are exported**
    + active leaves or storage tissues

<br/>

* **Sinks: sites that receive phloem sap**
    + all parts of plant

<br/>

* **Sugars actively loaded/unloaded into sieve elements**
    + at source and sink
    + changes water potential (both ends) 
    + water diffuses in/out driving sap
    + phloem under high pressure
    
<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:650px; WIDTH:350px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/phloem.jpg">

## Are there limits to moving water?
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:200px; LEFT:600px; WIDTH:500px; HEIGHT:400px" SRC="images/vessels.jpg">

<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">

* **Large trees move hundreds of gallons of water a day**

<br/>

* **Gravity**
    + harder and harder to move water
    + xylem less efficient @ top
    + theoretically, limits growth to 122-130 m

<br/>

* **Drying soil adds more tension**

</div>

## How can redwood trees grow so tall? Hyperion = 116m
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Cohesion tension theory**
    + plants use water properties to cheat gravity

<br/>

* **Cohesion: H~2~0 stick to other H~2~0 molecules**
    + via H bonds

<br/>

* **Adhesion: water sticks to non water molecules**
    + stick to sides of xylem tissues
    + is not pulled straight up!

<br/>

* **Transpiration pulls water under tension**
</div> 
 
<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:225px; LEFT:625px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:400px" SRC="images/water_drop.jpg">

## How can redwood trees grow so tall?
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **H~2~O also pulled in zig zag motion**
    + pits and perforations
    + tracheids are twisted

<br/>

* **Vascular tissue is tough**
    + high resistance of lignified walls
    + built not to collapse
  
<br/>

* **Hyperion tree near theoretical limit!** 
  
</div> 

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:475px; WIDTH:600px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/vessels_pits.jpg">

## Issues: Leaves (stomata) are sensitive to VPD
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">

* **Vapor Pressure Deficit: difference between moisture in air and how much moisture air can hold**
    + if *high* then the air is 'drier'
    + combo of temperature and humidity
    
<br/>

* **High VPD pulls has large impact on transpiration**

<br/>

* **If stressful, stomata should close**
    + stop excessive water loss

</div> 

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:500px; WIDTH:550px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/gs_vpd.jpg">

    + stomata closed

## Fix: Soils will refill without rain
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 55%;">

* **Capillary action and surface attraction draw in water**
    + clay soils have lots of 'pore' space
    + often stronger than gravity

<br/>

* **Potential energy (aka water potential) governs how water moves around in soil**
    + redistribution @ night
    + 'sponge' behavior during day

<br/>

* **Prolonged drought can impact the soil water potentials**

</div>
